prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So, the situation is that the husband set up his office in the bedroom instead of the basement, even though the basement would be quieter. His job is mostly conference calls, so he needs quiet. The wife has to keep the kids from disturbing him, which means the whole top floor is off-limits. She works from home too and handles most of the housework and kids. She can't even shower or do chores when he's on calls. She suggested the basement, but he prefers the bedroom for the view. Now they're fighting about who's the asshole.

First, I need to consider both sides. The husband chose the bedroom despite the wife's suggestion of the basement. The wife is trying to manage the household and her job, but his setup is causing her a lot of inconvenience. The question is whether the author (the wife) is in the wrong for not keeping him undisturbed.

The key points here are communication and compromise. The wife offered an alternative (basement) which would solve the problem, but he refused. The husband's choice affects her daily life significantly. Since he has the option to move to the basement where there's adequate space, and she can't promise silence in the bedroom, maybe he's the one being unreasonable. The wife isn't obligated to create a disturbance-free environment in the bedroom if he's the one who chose that location. So the author isn't in the wrong because she's standing her ground when her needs aren't being met. The husband should have considered her input and moved to the basement to avoid the conflict. Therefore, the answer should be B (No).
